Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Systems Electromagnetic Compatibility
Award.AbstractNarration:
This planned center site at Oklahoma State University for the I/UCRC for Electro-Magnetic Compatibility (CEMC) intends to leverage the institution?s scholarly contributions that have been of value to aerospace, naval, and space design applications that have focused on the ability of an external electromagnetic threat to couple current onto wire structures carrying command, control, and communication data. Recent work has been focused on establishing methodologies useful to industry related to enhancing shielding effectiveness of cable assemblies and gasket materials, determining effective absorptive materials to reduce overall available power in an enclosed environment, and the application of absorbing materials to reduce emissions from enclosures containing apertures. The planned site intends to leverage its measurement expertise associated with reverberation chamber applications to complement the CEMC's current capabilities.

Electromagnetic system interference is an increasingly pronounced problem in electronic systems as system frequencies continue to escalate. The planned site?s personnel have already been successfully engaged in providing translational research to industry (including the use of graduate level internships). The use of "engineering ambassadors" will provide an energetic connection to the applications of engineering that will be making a difference in the lives of people. A Student Leadership Council (SLC) will provide ongoing formative assessment of the program through regular SWOT analysis of student related outcomes connected with industry (internship quality) and research (mentoring quality). OSU is in a unique position to reach Native American communities in conjunction with Project Lead The Way and the strong CareerTech Programs throughout the state.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REFTAS lab (Robust Electromagnetic Field Testing and Simulation) at Oklahoma State University intended to coordinate with industry partners to work on identifying and solving problems that exist because of electromagnetic interference at a system level. The problems will extend from a simply enclosed cavity analysis to fully functional integrated platforms. Examples of the problems include predicting emissions from printed circuit boards radiating inside an enclosed cavity with apertures, validating the performance of different absorber materials placed inside cavities with complex operational electronics via simulation and measurements, electromagnetic compatibility problems while performing system integration in unmanned aerial systems (UAS). 
Intellectual Merit: The REFTAS lab provides key knowledge, experience and methods to define the optimal characterization metrics. Past work with the NAVY (SPAWAR and NAVAIR) has led to advances in measurement and simulation validation of models for rapid determination of potential susceptibility to hostile and friendly electromagnetic threats. 


Broader Impact: The REFTAS laboratory is leveraging Oklahoma State University’s interdisciplinary research between Electrical and Computer Engineering and Mechanical and Aerospace in the UAS area. Engineering Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) or Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are envisioned for many applications in which a manned presence is undesirable due to the dangerous environment, range of use, cost or simply improved performance over manned aircraft. With the impending FAA National Airspace integration plans for 2015, the ubiquity of UAS will lead to a proliferation of applications including battlefield surveillance and targeting, exploration, US border patrol, US infrastructure inspection (e.g., power lines, gas pipelines), agricultural applications, wildfire detection, and as a platform to carry atmospheric testing instrumentation for weather and climate analysis.  Undergraduate students (in internship programs and as successful graduates) and graduate students will be impacted by the REFTAS lab’s coordination with the I/UCRC.


This planning grant did not succeed in identifying partners that would be willing to pay the high member fees ($60k) required to join the MS&T team.

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2016
Modified by: Charles F Bunting
